(grumbles ) Why’d we even buy her that damned phone? She always turns it off.
Come to think of it, I heard someone turning on an engine this morning. Very early.
What motor? Dad's car’s right here. He points to a perfectly-maintained old Chevy in the open garage. And then he realizes the large covered carport is open.
Oh my god! He’s white as a ghost. He runs toward the carport. Lillia also shocked. She murmurs:  Scene 2 Page 3.

Jane! Mom and Dad are gone! And - can you believe it? - so is the Leisure Seeker!

(she is saying)... it was cold, but it was beautiful. Remember? Everything was covered by a layer of ice, shiny and transparent, like the world had been covered with glass. What are you doing? Can’t you keep it straight? In the cabin, objects begin to fall, plates and jars shak and slam. John slows down and pulls over.

(on the phone) «--good, we’ll be waiting for you. Yes, mile marker 21. Thanks! She hangs up the phone and turns to John.

I know you don’t, but we’re on vacation, right? Come on inside, don’t stay out here roasting in the sun. Can’t you see they’re just a couple of kids?
You folks need a hand? John looks at Ella: you see? But Ella quickly says:
No thanks, fellas. Triple A will be here soon.
How long ‘til they get here?

Good. He pulls out a knife.
(whispers) John, you fool.
Just be cool. We’re going to take your shit and then we'll go.
Gimme that phone!  Scene 35 Page 63. He points to the cell in Ella’s hand. She hands it to him SECOND KID (CONT’D) Your ring, too. Now the other guy’s pulled out a knife. He approaches Joh

(terrified) John, just do what they say. She slips off her ring and gives it to the Second Kid. An then she raises her hands, motioning to John to do the sa

...in the hand of the First Kid, who looks at the display

Already done it, hon, thanks. The First Kid drops the knife.  Scene 35 Page 65.

Your ring sucked anyway.

You fellas should consider evening classes. Get your diplomas! Turn things around. S’not too late! The Plymouth peels away. There’s a moment of silence. Ell still has the shotgun pointed.

Yes, darling, I know that your brother called. I didn’t answer because I was... held up. John smiles - he appreciates the pun. Jane speaks on her cell phone while striding across the campus of the college where she teaches. She juggles the phone and her paper-stuffed shoulder bag.
We're really worried, mother. Will’s getting desperate. I’m going to see him now.
Your brother is a Nervous Nelly. It’s nice of you to stay near him. Tell him that your father and I are having a grand old time. Jane's a bit amused by her mother’s response.

Darling, I wish you could see the sky here.
Okay, I get it, you aren’t going to tell me. How’s Dad? Ella shoots a look at her husband, who’s taking a big sip Canadian Club.
Full of beans. Oh, he still has his moments. But he’s doing well and he’s driving, which is a miracle. Would you like to speak with him? Ella passes the phone to her husband.

Jane?
Mom.

I know that it’s better than wandering around god-knows-where in a creaky camper. But you know best, I guess, because you talked to Dad, and you two are thick-as-thieves, even when he doesn’t even remember who we are.  Scene 37 Page 69.

Because you live two hours away and phone once a week and come on weekends for lunches that are cooked by me. What do you know about spending long afternoons with Dad when he doesn’t say a single thing that makes sense? You've been telling this story about how I’m Daddy’s Girl for years. It’s bullshit, Will.
Maybe it is. But it’s the only story I’ve got.
They're just doing what they’ve done their whole life. Staying together, the two of them. Jane wants to hug him, but Will backs away in a sulk.
There’s so much love between them that they forgot about us. Both of us.

Though I kinda doubt it. For years now, with Philip and me, it’s one quick kiss and goodnight.

Yes, I know, but it’s better that you come with me now. We’re gonna get a parking ticket. As she begins to drag him away, John shouts:
See you later, everybody! Make America great again! Those gathered nearby raise their beer bottles to toast J

(nodding agreement) Uh-huh...
You’ve voted Democrat your whole life. You volunteered for Walter Mondale. Don’t you remember how mad you got when I talked about voting for Reagan?
Ray-gun... ha, that’s funny -

Lillian!
Sweet Jesus, now you think I’m Lillian? Lillian is our next door neighbor. I’m your wife. L? LA?
Ella. My darling Ella. Excuse me. Oh, wow, my poor head. Ella continues to stare at him, trying to understand what going on inside his head.

The projector's carousel turns. All the slides are of Jan and Will: swimming in the ocean, stuffing cake into their mouths at a birthday party, Trick-or-Treating, rolling in piles of raked leaves, posing rigidly by the fireplace, sitting on Santa’s lap at a shopping center, close-up portraits... How’s Jim these days?

Promise me something.

If you love me, when the time comes, put the shotgun in my hands, put my finger on the trigger, remind me what I want to do, kiss me and walk away. It’s like mud season in Massachusetts. John instinctively pulls out the power cord to kill the painfu light, leaving them in near-darkness.
John, what have you done? Put it back in.
I can’t find the outlet.  Scene 39 Page 75. And then they hear what sounds like an animal in the bush

Let’s get the gun. Ella rises.
Let’s go inside. Muttering to herself.
